classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin)
Category 1 (digestive system, nervous system, blood system, cardiovascular system, kidney, liver, skin)
hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin)
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (digestive system, nervous system, blood system, cardiovascular system, kidney, liver, skin)
rationale: In a 2-year mixed diet study using rats, the effect of the substance on the bile duct was noted at the dose of 12 mg/kg bw (DFGOT Vol. 21 (2002)). Thus, the substance falls under Category 2 (digestive system). In a mixed diet study using dogs, no serious symptoms were noted (Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO) (2008); DFGOT Vol. 21 (2002)); however, the dose given was 8 mg/kg bw/day, which was below the guidance dose value. According to EHC 224 (2001) on arsenic and its inorganic compounds in relation to humans, gastrointestinal tract disorder; nervous disorder; effects on the blood system; and abnormalities in cardiovascular system, kidney, and liver were observed. Thus, target organs for these substances are the gastrointestinal tract, heart, brain, and kidney. In addition, the skin, bone marrow and peripheral nervous system are also affected by this substance. Moreover, according to ACGIH (2001), the upper respiratory tract and lung are also affected. Based on these reports, this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, and skin).

Based on the description in the humans of arsenic and inorganic arsenics compounds, "gastrointestinal disturbances, neuropathy, effect on blood systems,  and disorders on cardiovascular systems, kidney,  and liver were observed the long term administration of inorganic arsenic. Target organ are gastrointestinal,heart,brains and kidney. The skin, marrow and peripheral nervous systems are also affected " (EHC 224 (2001), and PIM(Poisons Information Monographs) G042 (WHO/IPCS, 1996)),  it was classified into Category 1 (a digestive tract, a nervous systems, blood systems, the kidney, liver, respiratory system, skin)

According to EHC 224 (2001) and Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO (2008)), induction of micronuclei and chromosomal aberrations were observed in several in vivo tests using mouse bone marrow. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 2. As additional background information, the dominant lethal test using mice was negative (EHC 224 (2001), Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO) (2008)).

Although there is two or more knowledge which induces micronucleus/chromosome aberration in the in vivo mouse marrow from description of EHC 224 (2001), it is negative in the mouse dominant lethal tests. So it is set as 2.

rationale: Classified into Category 1, since acute toxicity was Category 1, and it is a metallic compound, behavior in water and bioaccumulative potential are unknown.

Since inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to irritate human eyes (HSG 70, 1992; PIM 042, 1996), this substance was classified into Category 2.

There is the description that the similar descriptions in humans "(may) irritates to skin, eye, and membrane" (SITTIG (4th, 2002) of Priority 2 and Chemical Safety Data Sheets Vol.4 a/The Royal Society of Chemistry (1991) equivalent to Priority 2). So it was classified into Category 2. It is difficult to subdivide the Category 2A and 2B.

Inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to cause irritation (DFGOT vol. 21, 2005). However, since no further information is available, classification is not possible.

It was set as Category 2 from description of "which indicates stimulant to the skin" on Chemical Safety Data Sheets Vol.4 a/The Royal Society of Chemistry (1991) equivalent to Priority 2. Moreover, SITTIG (47th, 2002) has description of "irritation may be indicated in the skin, an eye, and membrane."
It is stable in contact with water. (According to Merck (13th, 2001) and Sax (11th, 2004), it is readily soluble in water.)

classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)

Category 1 (digestive system, cardiovascular system, nervous system, blood system, kidney),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)

Causes damage to organs (digestive system, cardiovascular system, nervous system, blood system, kidney)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
rationale: No test results were found on single exposure to this substance other than lethal effects. In humans, the following acute toxic effects by arsenic compounds are documented: symptoms of the gastrointestinal tract, cardiovascular system, nerves, and blood system; conjunctivitis and dermatitis as well as irritation to the nasal mucosa, pharynx, and trachea; frequent urination or anuria due to a blockage of renal tubules with clots of hemoglobin (IARC 23 (1980)); depression of bone marrow functions; and hepatomegaly (EHC 224 (2001)). In accordance with these reports, the digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver were considered to be target organs, and this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver).

The substance was classified as Category 1 (gastrointestinal system, cardio-vascular system, nervous system, blood system and kidneys) and Category 3 (airway irritant). Based on the report that in the forms of the arsenic and inorganic arsenic compounds it causes "symptoms in the gastrointestinal organs, disorders in the functions of the cardio-vascular and nervous systems, myelosuppression, alteration in the blood system and nephropathy" in humans (EHC 224 (2001)), and based on a similar report in PIM (Poisons Information Monographs) G042 (WHO/IPCS, 1996), and as well as the reports of "airway irritant properties" in PIM (Poisons Information Monographs) G042 (WHO/IPCS, 1996) and HSG (Health and Safety Guides) 70 (WHO/IPCS, 1992).

hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
rationale:
In a 3-generation study in mice given this substance in drinking water, there was a trend toward a decrease number of pups per litter in all three generations of the treated group (ATSDR, 2007). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 2.
According to EHC 224 (2001), which is a List 1 information source, description for arsenic and arsenic compounds suggested toxic effects of the substance on reproduction in humans; in addition, fetal toxicity and teratogenic effects were seen at doses that produce maternal toxicity in animal tests. Based on this information, the substance was classified into Category 2. Catalog of Teratogenic Agents (2004), which is equivalent to List 1 sources, supports the conclusion that inorganic arsenic is not teratogenic to humans.

It was considered as Category 2 from the description about the humans of EHC 224 (2001) of Priority 1 "effect on reproductive is suggested" and knowledge in animal "fetus toxicity and teratogenicity at the dosage in which maternal toxicity is observed " and the description in the humans of Catalog of teratogenic agents (2004) equivalent to Priority 1"the conclusion that inorganic arsenic is not teratogen in humans is supported."
Since arsenic and arsenic compounds are rated as carcinogenic to humans according to IARC Suppl. 7 (1987), ACGIH-TLV (2008), and MAK/BAT (2007), the substances were classified into Category 1A.

Since all existing classified materials in IARC Suppl.7 (1987), ACGHI-TLV (2004), and MAK/BAT (2004) are categorized into human carcinogens (as arsenic and arsenic cmpds), it was classified into Category 1A.
